image.altText: A child sitting in front of a TV screen, looking towards the screen.

props.synopsis: While their parents try their hardest to keep them safe, fed and at school, children are sleeping in tents in the dry ironbark forest of central Victoria, where the extremes of homelessness and bushfire risk are converging.

title.children: 'I don't want to raise my kids into this': Families left with no choice but to live in tents in the bush

image.altText: Ayman Dhlan

props.synopsis: Ayman Dhlan says he feels a responsibility to answer every message in his WhatsApp chat from people trying to get their family out of Gaza. He's still waiting for news of whether his own mother, brother and sisters have made the list.

title.children: How this Melbourne dad became a one-man consulate, helping Australians and their families get out of Gaza

image.altText: a weather map of new south wales showing the heatwave and high temperatures for saturday november 8

props.synopsis: Without a doubt the one topic of discussion this weekend is the weather. From a cyclone, to heatwave, record rain and flooding— Australia has it all.

title.children: Cyclone, heatwaves and flooding dominate Australia's weekend weather of extremes

image.altText: A man wearing a suit in front of an Australian flag.

props.synopsis: There's much hype on the first Tuesday of every month when the Reserve Bank announces its decision on interest rates. But quietly a far greater financial burden is being placed on households, writes David Taylor.

title.children: Interest rate hikes are hurting, no doubt, but there's a way bigger drain on your household budget

image.altText: A girl sits in the doorway of a makeshift tent at a camp

props.synopsis: Israel said on Friday that the military was rounding up Palestinian men in northern Gaza for interrogation, searching for Hamas militants, while desperate Palestinians in the south crowded into an ever-shrinking area, and the UN warned that its aid operation is "in tatters."

title.children: Israeli troops round up Palestinian men in northern Gaza as US blocks ceasefire bid at UN Security Council

image.altText: A box of pills and drugs.

props.synopsis: Police have arrested six people and raided properties in three jurisdictions, seizing millions of dollars worth of steroids and prescription drugs as well as cash and vehicles.

title.children: Police make multiple arrests as they break up nationwide steroid and prescription drug syndicate

image.altText: A pensive Nick Kyrgios looks down as he stands on a practice court with his racquet.

props.synopsis: Ongoing injury concerns force Nick Kyrgios out of next month's Australian Open at Melbourne Park, with the 28-year-old describing the decision as "heartbreaking".

title.children: Kyrgios announces he won't play Australian Open via OnlyFans account

image.altText: A white gallery wall painted variously with black text and large patches of red and black.

props.synopsis: Leading artist Mike Parr has been dropped by prominent Jewish gallerist Anna Schwartz this week following a performance that included references to the conflict in Gaza.

title.children: Australian artist dropped by gallery of 36 years over performance that referenced Israel-Gaza War

image.altText: Calf looks at the camera.

props.synopsis: The federal government issues a Tasmanian abattoir with a draft notice to suspend its export licence for a year after confronting footage obtained by animal rights activists raises questions about slaughter practices. WARNING: This story contains depictions of animals in distress.

title.children: 'Never seen anything like this': Abattoir facing export suspension after footage released

image.altText: A man dressed in a traditional white Dishdasha walks underneath a towering yellow dome.

props.synopsis: To the casual observer, this year's UN climate talks in the United Arab Emirates could be interpreted as a stonking, resounding success. But underlying all of it was something far more difficult, and far more contentious, writes Daniel Mercer.

title.children: As the world records its hottest year on record, climate talks in Dubai drill down to one central issue

image.altText: Jennifer Garner smiles, posing in a Christmas-themed photo with Ed Helms dressed as a candy cane.

props.synopsis: Every year in December, countless new festive films flood streaming services — but they're not always quality. What is it about "bad" Christmas movies that viewers love?

title.children: There's a psychological reason why you find comfort in mediocre Christmas movies

image.altText: An aerial image of the Fully Light Casino in Laukkai.

props.synopsis: Fourteen years after the warlord Peng Jiasheng was betrayed and forced to relinquish control of Kokang, the region in Myanmar's north-east that he had ruled for decades, his family are poised to finally get revenge.

title.children: Laukkai is a notorious den of online scams — and the prize in one family's 14-year quest for revenge

image.altText: Actor Ryan O'Neal and his partner Farrah Fawcett at a movie premiere

props.synopsis: O'Neal — the long-time partner of Farrah Fawcett — was nominated in 1970 for a Best Actor Oscar for his role in the romantic tear-jerker Love Story.

title.children: Paper Moon and Love Story actor Ryan O'Neal dies 'peacefully' aged 82

image.altText: Justice Gregory Geason looks off camera.

props.synopsis: The appearance of a Supreme Court judge in a court charged with emotional abuse and assault last week has attracted a huge amount of media attention. But what the Tasmanian government did next turned a drama into a saga.

title.children: How did a Supreme Court judge's court appearance spill into the political arena?

image.altText: Globemasters in close formation

props.synopsis: Exercise Global Dexterity, involving one of the largest aircraft in use, the C-17 Globemaster, brings Australian, British and US air forces together in Queensland for the first time.

title.children: Globemasters roar across Queensland skies in joint military exercise finale

image.altText: Two people look at an engraved stone slab.

props.synopsis: You could make the argument, as unpopular as it might be, that some colonial looters and their buyers did the world a favour by keeping precious works locked away. But that only flies if you now give them back, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: It was once so easy to become an international art thief that I nearly joined in — but now there's no excuse

image.altText: A man with a toothbrush moustache, wearing a suit, looks directly to camera against a blue background

props.synopsis: In 2004, an Indian intelligence officer suspected of leaking classified information to a foreign power seemingly vanished into thin air. Piecing together the factual and fictional accounts of the Rabinder Singh case reveals a desperate race to catch a double agent and his CIA puppeteer.

title.children: A tip-off alerted this Indian double agent he was about to be caught. Somehow, he managed to disappear

image.altText: Gangsta Granny 2

props.synopsis: Gangsta Granny now has more than 1.7 million followers on TikTok, making her one of Australia's "mega influencers".

title.children: When Judy's grandson told her she'd gone viral, she thought she'd made people sick

image.altText: people hold up phones to take images of a panda in a zoo enclosure

props.synopsis: China's pandas are not just pandas. They're diplomats. You're friendly to China? You get a panda. You criticise China? You get no pandas.

title.children: Panda diplomacy: How China uses pandas to signal which countries they like, and which ones they don't

image.altText: Four women stand on the beach holding surfboards wearing different coloured rash vests.

props.synopsis: Phillip Island surfer Hannah Eisen remembers the biggest adrenaline rush of her life. Now she's helping local girls have that thrill in the ocean.

title.children: Hannah remembers her surf club feeling like a boys' domain. Now she runs it

image.altText: Severe Tropical Cyclone Jasper, a category 4 system, is moving to the south through the northeastern Coral Sea

props.synopsis: Jasper remains a category four system but is expected to drop to a category three this evening, and further weaken to category two by late Sunday or Monday.

title.children: Cyclone Jasper is 'unusually slow' but could re-intensify as it crosses the Queensland coast

image.altText: An Olympic flag flies in the air during the 2020 Tokyo Games.

props.synopsis: The International Olympic Committee says individual Russian and Belarusian athletes who qualify in their sport for the 2024 Paris Games can take part as neutrals without flags, emblems or anthems at the event next year.

title.children: Russian, Belarusian athletes to participate at Paris Olympics as neutrals

image.altText: A photo of a large crowd at the Laneway Festival in Sydney

props.synopsis: Temperatures in Sydney are expected to soar today as thousands attend the sold-out Epik festival at the showground in Western Sydney.

title.children: 'People die from overheating': Warning for Sydney festivalgoers as temperature to hit 40C

image.altText: Rebecca Evans on court during a match.

props.synopsis: Rebecca Evans has earned a formidable on-court reputation in powerchair football, but is the only woman on her team. And it highlights a much bigger problem.

title.children: Women have always been under-represented in sport. The disparity for those with a disability is even wider

image.altText: A thermal image showing a hot yellow coloured koala hugging a cooler purple tree

props.synopsis: Snot bubbles, tree-hugging and flyby belly dipping are just some of the ingenious ways Australian animals keep cool during a heatwave.

title.children: Feeling the heat? Here's how some of Australia's most iconic animals keep cool

image.altText: Alyssa Healy looks to her right during an ODI in the women's Ashes series.

props.synopsis: Having already filled in as national captain, Alyssa Healy is officially named Australia skipper following Meg Lanning's decision to retire from international cricket.

title.children: Healy confirmed as Australia's full-time captain

image.altText: A man in a suit stands behind a lectern at the national press club.

props.synopsis: The NDIS is often described as having become the only lifeboat on the ocean for people with disabilities. It was also always one of the most complex and ambitious bits of public policy in the world, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: The NDIS has many issues that need solving. The most pressing is what happens to the kids it cannot help

image.altText: Orange flames and thick black smoke billow from a burning factory.

props.synopsis: A blaze in a factory in Melbourne's south-east is now under control but firefighters continue to fight the blaze and have not been able to enter the building.

title.children: One person 'unaccounted-for' in factory fire in Melbourne's south-east

image.altText: A man with a septum piercing and white beard and long hair wearing a beanie outside while it snows

props.synopsis: ABC Investigations has uncovered the extensive digital footprints of Donald Day Jr, who was charged in connection to a deadly shooting in Wieambilla, Queensland. His posting history reveals a conspiratorial worldview where violence is inevitable.

title.children: Don Day Jr's digital footprints reveal a state of mind that saw enemies, conspiracies everywhere

image.altText: Australia's Defence Minister and Disability Minister Linda Reynolds speaks during a press conference in Washington, July 2020.

props.synopsis: The WA Senator filed her latest lawsuit in Western Australia's Supreme Court on Monday and is seeking an apology and damages.

title.children: Liberal Senator Linda Reynolds sues the ACT government and its former top prosecutor for defamation

image.altText: Caucasian man in a dark suit, white shirt, red hair, leaving a court house.

props.synopsis: Prince Harry sued publisher Associated Newspapers over an article that stated he tried to keep secret a separate legal fight with the British government over his publicly-funded police protection.

title.children: UK judge rules against Prince Harry in early stage of libel claim against newspaper

image.altText: A man in a suit speaking to a man in military uniform, in a ballroom during a ceremony

props.synopsis: Russian President Vladimir Putin has told soldiers who had fought in the Ukraine war that he would run for president again in the 2024 election.

title.children: Vladimir Putin tells Russian soldiers he will run for president at election

image.altText: A woman and man both leaving court separately with their faces blurred.

props.synopsis: A former couple who used to own a bakery in regional South Australia are found guilty of historical sex charges involving an underage employee.

title.children: Former SA couple found guilty of historical sex charges

image.altText: A close up of yellow and gold Christmas beetle

props.synopsis: The famous Christmas beetle usually comes out in force at this time of year, but one scientist is noticing a surge in sightings of another not-so-welcome bug.

title.children: The invasive pest being mistaken for beloved Christmas beetles
